instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S3_L: What is PM_SLP_S3_L? PM_SLP_S3_L puts the machine to sleep in an S3 state when it is asserted, the _L means it is asserted when it is low voltage. When this signal is 3.3v the machine will be asked to turn on S0 power rails and begin the bootup process.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on, main power rails are present
threads.message:
It's seems to me that all power lines needed for this to start are present:
- <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 8,6V
- <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3,41V
- <SIGNAL>PPV5_S5</SIGNAL> = 5V
- PP3v3 = 3,3V
- <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL> = 3,3V
- <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> = 3,3V

So whats the next step here?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on, main power rails are present
threads.message: Any  S0 voltages present? CPU Vcore?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on, main power rails are present
threads.message: No S0 lines as far as I can tell

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on, main power rails are present
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on, main power rails are present
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on, main power rails are present
threads.message: Come on, do some diagnoses, I can't drag it all out. If <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> is present then all S0 rails are being told to turn on.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on, main power rails are present
threads.message: Okei, sorry, of course. I get nothing on pin 4 on <CHIP>U8180</CHIP>, seems like I have a short

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on, main power rails are present
threads.message:
What is the short to, and on what pin? On pin 4?

Look at what <CHIP>U8180</CHIP> does. It's powered by <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> on pin 5, and if it has voltage on pins 1 and 2, it will shoot out 3.3v on pin 4. Does it have voltage on pin 1 and 2? Does it have <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> on pin 5?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on, main power rails are present
threads.message:
Oh, Pin 4 is short to ground. Yes I have 3.3V on Pin 5 and of course 3.3 on 1 and 2 as well. I have tried removing <RESISTOR>R8185</RESISTOR>-<RESISTOR>R8187</RESISTOR>. I have also removed <CHIP>U3210</CHIP> and <CHIP>U7870</CHIP> but the short is still there.
As far as I can tell I have removed every component on that rail now so I'm afraid the short is in the board itself.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on, main power rails are present
threads.message: <CHIP>U3210</CHIP> and <CHIP>U7870</CHIP> are also on this rail!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on, main power rails are present
threads.message: Yes they are, Thats why I removed them. Anyway, I have come a bit further, found the short and have put the components back. I now starts but CPU Vcore is missing so I'll have to figure out why that is.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on, main power rails are present
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on, main power rails are present
threads.message: Something under <CHIP>U3210</CHIP> that I didn't se at first

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on, main power rails are present
threads.message: So did that fix the issue?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on, main power rails are present
threads.message: No, not entirely, the fan starts (occasionally), but I get 0V on the CPU. I have to figure out why that is.
